questions.question: Which instruction is required at the beginning of every Dockerfile?
questions.explanation: The 'FROM' instruction initializes a new build stage and sets the Base Image for subsequent instructions.

questions.question: What is the difference between CMD and ENTRYPOINT?

options.text: CMD is for scripts, ENTRYPOINT is for binaries
ENTRYPOINT sets the executable, CMD sets default arguments that can be overridden
CMD sets the executable, ENTRYPOINT can be overridden

questions.explanation: ENTRYPOINT defines the command that will run when the container starts. CMD provides default arguments for that entrypoint which the user can easily override at runtime.

questions.question: Which instruction is used to set the primary folder where commands like RUN and COPY will execute?
questions.explanation: WORKDIR sets the working directory for any subsequent RUN, CMD, ENTRYPOINT, COPY, and ADD instructions.

questions.question: Why should you run 'npm install' or 'pip install' BEFORE copying your entire source code into the image?

options.text: To make the build faster by leveraging layer caching
Because Docker requires dependencies to be installed first
To save RAM during the build
It doesn't matter where you put it

questions.explanation: Docker caches layers. By copying only the dependency files (like package.json) first and running install, Docker only needs to re-run the installation if the dependencies change, rather than every time you edit a line of code.

questions.question: Which command is used to build an image from a Dockerfile in the current directory and give it a tag?
questions.explanation: The 'docker build' command builds an image from a Dockerfile. The -t flag (tag) allows you to name the image, and the '.' specifies the build context (the current directory).
